entry.name: Global detection of Protein Kinase D-dependent phosphorylation events in nocodazole-treated human cells.
entry.description: TRANCHE KEY: oNBq7tFA2/2lHQUNY7nrGTBtAeiUV3VUnKTDSrMnwaOIArgwxHLQLzAS3tQIfkxyBTtleFn34alcVRBS6acUbvOex/AAAAAAAESnXA== Data set 1, original data file: F186791.mgf. Data published as part of Mol Cell Proteomics. 2012 Apr 10 ([[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22496350 PubMed]]). From the Abstact: {{i}}Protein kinase D (PKD) is a cytosolic serine/threonine kinase implicated in regulation of several cellular processes such as response to oxidative stress, directed cell migration, invasion, differentiation and fission of the vesicles at the trans-Golgi network. Its variety of functions must be mediated by numerous substrates; however, only a couple of PKD substrates have been identified so far. Here we perform SILAC - based quantitative phosphoproteomic analysis to detect phosphorylation events dependent on PKD1 activity in human cells. We compare relative phosphorylation levels between constitutively active and kinase-dead PKD1 strains of HEK293 cells, both treated with nocodazole, a microtubule-depolymerizing reagent which disrupts the Golgi complex and activates PKD1.{{/i}}
